cards.back:
Execution time doesn't depend on input size.

Examples: Array access, hash lookup

Time grows slowly with input size (halving search space).

Examples: Binary search, balanced trees

log₂(10⁹) ≈ 30

Time proportional to input size.

Examples: Single loop, linear search

Double n → double time

Slightly worse than linear, much better than quadratic.

Examples: FFT, merge sort, heap sort

Time grows with square of input.

Examples: Nested loops, bubble sort

Double n → 4× time

Common in matrix operations.

Examples: Matrix multiply, Gaussian elimination

Double n → 8× time

O(n log n) vs O(n²) for direct DFT

For n = 10⁶:
Direct: 10¹² ops
FFT: ~20 × 10⁶ ops

50,000× speedup!

O(n³) for n×n system

For n = 1000: ~10⁹ operations
For n = 10000: ~10¹² operations (hours)

cards.front: Space complexity for dense n×n matrix
cards.back:
O(n²) memory

1000×1000 doubles = 8 MB
10000×10000 doubles = 800 MB

Use for large SPARSE systems.

Iterative (CG, GMRES): O(kn)
Direct (Gaussian): O(n³)

For sparse systems, k << n.
